Works

2021 -

kombu. a.k.a AIEdu

The Hands-on AI Education Material

AIEdu is a machine learning experience platform for students new to AI to understand how it works and how to use it. You can easily experience the process of creating your own hand-drawn dataset, training a machine learning model in Tensorflow, and then using your own model to classify hand-drawn images. 

Even though this system requires no coding at all, it actually runs Tensorflow on a server, so you can ask yourself, "What can machine learning do?" What can we do to improve learning accuracy?" and "How can we improve the learning accuracy?" through actual trial and error.

  • kombu.
  • AiEdu Introduction
  • Practical report on AI learning on the subject of image classification at the high school level
  • Development of an iPad application to experience machine learning on the subject of image classification

2020 -

Photrip

Browse through the photos to discover your next destination

An app for finding travel destinations developed together with NeWalk Ltd. We implemented a new experience where you stock only the things you like from among the beautiful images that appear at random, and before you know it, you have an itinerary.

  • NeWalk, Inc.

2020 -

Credy

The next generation of loan recording apps

This was developed as an application for recording and sharing the amount of advances in order to support the management of payments when splitting a bill with good friends or when travelling. It was born out of the developers' daily worries about whether there was a way to easily record advances and remember how much to pay, and they implemented an app that they actually wanted to use. In implementing the app, we aimed to challenge the latest technology, and it is an experimental app that actively uses the latest mechanisms presented at WWDC19.

  • Credy - AppStore

2015 -

Kasgai

The Computational Thinking Development Material

The core system of the method for fostering computational thinking devised, comprising Kegaki (a system for creating and evaluating Venn diagrams), Yattoko (a system for classifying and evaluating flowcharts) and Kanna (a system for conducting exercises to convert data created on Yattoko into programme code). The system consists of the following. The aim of the system is to help students develop a logical way of thinking by visualising and verbalising the classification of things. (For details, see the paper below.) Demonstrations of the system have been conducted in high schools and universities and the results published in a paper.

  • Kasgai
  • Design and development of an assembled Venn diagram/Yes/No chart learning environment for a classification task aimed at fostering Computational Thinking, and evaluation of its pilot operation
  • Design, development and evaluation of an assembled Venn diagram-Yes/No chart learning system to foster Computational Thinking
  • Learning Effectiveness of Computational Thinking in a Simple Classification Task While Using a Yes/No Chart Learning System Compared to Using a Visual Programming Learning System
  • Design and development of a block programming environment with mutual evaluation capabilities
  • Development of an HTML & JavaScript block programming environment to enable the creation of interactive web content.
  • Development of a block programming environment that implements simultaneous editing functions to facilitate collaborative learning
  • A Block Programming Environment Enabling Online Peer Assessment for Promoting Collaborative Learning
  • Development of a Visual Programming Environment that Enables Simultaneous Editing to Promote Collaborative Learning
  • Development of a Block Programming Environment that Enables the Creation of Web Contents using HTML and JavaScript
  • Developing a Block Programming Environment to Create Web Game Contents Using HTML and JavaScript

2019 - 2019

LuuX

Test implementation of a method of operating household appliances by "eye contact"

 A device operation system for voice-controlled operation of a device, comprising: a camera installed in each of the devices that captures a user; a line-of-sight detection unit that recognises an image captured by the camera and detects a user's line of sight; a UI providing unit that notifies a user that the device in which the camera that captured the image determined to be a target for viewing is in a command standby state; a command determining unit that recognises a sound made by a user who has been prompted to operate the device and controls the device with the command; and a command specifying the command. The equipment operation system is provided with a UI providing unit that provides a user interface to notify the user that the equipment is in a command waiting state and prompts the user to operate the equipment, a command judging unit that recognises the voice of the user prompted to operate the equipment and judges the command, and a control unit that controls the equipment in the standby state by specifying the command.

  • Proposal of an operation method based on 'eye contact' with household appliances and development of smart lights using this method.

2018 - 2018

Deliver Box

Puzzle game for determining transport routes to foster Computational Thinking.

The purpose of this study is to develop the game application Deliver Box, which aims to foster Computational Thinking (hereafter referred to as CT), and to propose its relationship with CT and a method for fostering CT. The aim is to develop a programming mindset based on CT and organised in relation to logical thinking. One of the characteristics of programming education in Japan is that coding is not mandatory and that programming is conducted within each subject area, so it is important to develop CT within each subject area. To achieve this, we developed the game application Deliver Box, which can be run on Playground. A learning model incorporating experiential learning was proposed to develop CTs using this application.

  • Proposal for the development and use of a game application "Deliver Box" aimed at fostering Computational Thinking.
  • Development of Deliver Box, a Playground game application oriented towards fostering Computational Thinking
  • Development of DeliverBox, a puzzle game application that fosters computational thinking

2017 - 2019

n-Queen for Education

n-Queen Problem Simulator

An app for playing 8-Queen, a game that generalises the puzzle to n Queens, on iOS. The app was developed as a teaching aid to promote algorithmic thinking. To improve 'algorithmic thinking', it is important to understand the structure of the problem and to be able to explain the solution. This has already been pointed out in metacognitive research, and we thought that the n-Queen puzzle might be useful for developing these skills. The application made it possible to freely perform Rotation, Flip, Undo, etc., making it even more useful for education compared to the n-Queen on paper. Details are presented in the following paper.

  • n-Queen Problem for Education - App Store
  • Development of iOS Software n-Queens Problem for Education and Its Application for Promotion of Computational Thinking
  • Software Review: "n-Queen Problem for Education" an iOS application for fostering computational thinking
  • Excellent Student Paper Award Outstanding Prize, IEEE GCCE 2019

  • A direct interview with Yuji Sasaki of Kwansei Gakuin Senior High School, who was selected for the scholarship slot at WWDC17! - The fun of programming lies in its infinite possibilities

2016 - 2018

e-Stat Junior

Minister of Internal Affairs Award: Statistics Portal Site

The e-Stat of the Statistics Bureau of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications has been redesigned to be easy to use for beginners. Information can be searched using three different approaches: unit scope-focused search, information acquisition by region, and keyword search. The system has been made easy to incorporate into educational settings by allowing previews of information and the ability to select and discard information on the system. The system received the Minister of Internal Affairs and Communications Award at the STAT-DASH Grand Prix 2016. The system was developed by the Statistics Bureau of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications and has been in operation since June 2018.

  • Kids Stat - Statistics Bureau, Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications
  • STAT DASH Grand Prix 2016 List of award-winning entries and Minister of Internal Affairs and Communications Award
  • "Kids' Stat" a portal site for statistical learning for elementary and junior high school students
  • Minister of Internal Affairs Award, STAT-DASH Grand Prix 2016

2016 - 2016

KabeCom

New communication tools through the "wall"

A whiteboard-like environment, known as a Kabe, is shared remotely to support the sharing of stock information.

  • Cybozu Award, U22 Programming Contest
  • Cybozu Award, ICT Challenge+R

2015 - 2016

Find! Kirigami

Interactive Art Using Kirigami

To enhance an audience's immersive experience of a media artwork, it is important to provide the audience with more than one channel through which they can take the initiative to participate in the artwork. It is also crucial to provide a natural interaction between the artwork and its audience. Based on these ideas, we developed an interactive media artwork called "Find Kirigami!" inspired by kirigami, a traditional Japanese paper-cutting play activity.

  • Find Kirigami!: an Augmented Papercutting Play Activity Realized with Tablet Terminals
  • The Commerce and Information Policy Bureau Prize, U22 Programming Contest
  • Sakura-Internet Award, U22 Programming Contest
  • Useful Award, U22 Programming Contest
